question: Initial stage of clinical union of bone is equivalent to
exp: The first signs of union are seen in stage of hard callus formation A. Clinical sign: fracture is no more mobile B. Radilogical sign: callus is seen on X ray *hard callus is immature woven bone* Ref: Maheshwari 9th/e p 12
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Diagnostic sign of a fracture
exp: Diagnostic sign of a fracture is abnormal mobility at fracture site. Pathognomic sign of traumatic and fresh fracture is crepitus. ref: maheswari, 5thedition, page no. 12
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Callus formation is seen between what duration of fracture healing
exp: Stage of callus: This stage lasts for about 4-12 weeks. In this stage, the granulation tissue differentiates fuher and creates osteoblasts. These cells lay down an intercellular matrix which soon becomes impregnated with calcium salts. This results in the formulation of the callus also called woven bone. The callus is the first sign of union visible on X-rays, usually 3 weeks after the fracture. The formation of this bridge of woven bone impas good strength to the fracture. Callus formation is slower in adults than in children, and in coical bones than in cancellous bones. Ref: Maheswari; Essential Ohopaedics; 9th edition; Anatomy of Bone and Fracture Healing; Page no: 11
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Blue sclera is seen in all except
exp: In keratoconus, there are no scleral changes. Blue sclerae are characteristic of connective tissue disorders like osteogenesis imperfecta, Marfan's syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Ref: Maheshwari 6e pg 316.
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: which of the following is a Bone resorption marker is?
exp: Deoxypyridinoline (DPD) in urine, which reflects systemic bone resorption, is considered most useful for assessing the effects of osteoporosis treatment.
opa: Serum propeptide of type I procollagen
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: All the following are advantages of the Jaipur foot over the conventional SACH foot Except
exp: Traditionally, the terminal device of a lower limb prosthesis is a prosthetic foot, called SACH foot. It is a simple device that has a wooden core surrounded by a solid rubber foot. This permits a combination of stiffness with pliability. The cushioned heel absorbs the impact of heel strike. In India, at Jaipur, SACH foot has been modified in a number of ways to make it suitable for barefoot walking. Essentially, these modifications are: (i) appearance of the foot is that of a normal foot; and (ii) it allows movement at forefoot and midfoot, making walking on uneven surfaces easier. It is not electrically operated. Ref: Maheswari; Essential Ohopedics; 5th edition; Page no: 332
opa: Appearance of the Jaipur foot is that of normal foot
opb: It is suitable for bare foot walking
opc: Allows movement at fore foot and midfoot
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: what Type of collagen is found in bone?
exp: Type 1 collagen fibres, derived from tropocollagen molecules produced by osteoblasts, make up over 80 percent of unmineralized matrix. They form a network which emboides a mucopolysaccharide(proteoglycans)ground substance and also acts as a scaffold on which the mineral component-crystalline hydroxyapatite is deposited. ref: apley&; s textbook, 9th edition page no. 118
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: The bone matrix has the following crystals
exp: The bone is made up of bone cells and extracellular matrix. The matrix consists oftwo types of materials, organic and inorganic. The organic matrix is formed by the collagen, which forms 30-35% of dry weight of a bone. The inorganic matrix is primarily calcium and phophorus salts, especially hydroxyapatite. It constitutes about 65-70% of dry weight of a bone. ref: maheswari, 5th edition page no. 9
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Non-union is a complication of which of the following?
exp: Sites of non union: Femur neck fracture Scaphoid fracture Tibia fracture Lateral condyle humerus fracture Fracture lower 3rd ulna Radiological features of nonunion of scaphoid: Rounding of fracture surfaces Fractures become sharply defined Cystic changes occur in one or both fragments Ref: Maheshwari and Mhaskar 9th ed pg 116.
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Headlight in fog appearance in retina
exp: White focal retinitis with overlying vitreous inflammation ("headlight in the fog") is seen in Toxoplasmosis
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Intramembranous ossification is seen in which bones?
exp: Endochondral ossification "Most of long bones, veebrae, pelvis, skull base bones Intramembranous ossification: skull vault, maxilla, most of the mandible, clavicle ref: maheswari book of ohopedics 9th ed
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Indicators of bone formation includes all of following except
exp: Markers of bone formation: Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase * Serum osteocalcin * Serum peptide of type 1 collagen Markers of bone resorption: Urine and serum crosslinked &; N&; telopeptidase * Urine and serum crosslinked &; C&; telopeptidase * Urine total free deoxypyridinoline ref: maheswari, 9th edition, page no. 12
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: What is March fracture?
exp: March fracture, also known as Insufficiency fracture is a stress or fatigue fractures of the metatarsals paicularly the second metatarsal bone. It is more often seen in military personnel who induge in frequent and prolonged marching. ref: john ebnezar textbook, page no. 288
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: All are True about fracture healing except:
exp: Compression at fracture site improves healing by inducing callus formation Compression enhances the rate of union in cancellous bone. In coical bones, compression at the fracture site enhances rigidity of fixation, and possibly results in primary bone healing. Ref: Maheshwari 9th ed pg 12.
opc: Compression at fracture site causes nonunion
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Rate of newly synthesized osteoid mineralization can be best estimated by
exp: Rate of mineralisation is determined by Labelled Tetracycline. ref: maheswari, 5th edition page no. 12
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing

question: Frieberg's disease involve
exp: condition characterized by infarction and fracture of the metatarsal head. Most often seen in 2nd metatarsal (MT) head, paicularly the dorsal aspect4th and 5th MT rarely affected Bony nucleus of epiphysis is affected in osteochondritis Ref: Maheshwari and Mhaskar 6e pg 318.
topic_name: Anatomy and physiology of bone and fracture healing
